The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of thepast week. .During the previous seven days Bomber Command had dropped 1,320 tons of bombs and 172 mines. The attack onCologne had been hampered by weather conditions, but the raidon the Creusot Works had been very successful. The attackingbombers had flown some 1,700 miles, making a big detour via the bay of Biscay.The War Cabinet Requested the Chief of the Air Staff to convey theircongratulations on the success of this operation to theAir Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Bomber Command.Details were given of the operations of Coastal and FighterCommands. In the home theatre, the enemy had lost 9 destroyed,2 probably destroyed and 2 damaged. Our losses had been fighters, 35 bombers and 6 Coastal Command aircraft.Enemy attacks at the beginning of the previous week hadbeen heavy but their bomber sorties were now getting fewer. Theenemy losses for the previous seven days had been 102 destroyed,45 probably destroyed and 111 damaged. Our losses had been 34fighters destroyed, but a number of pilots had been saved.There had been a slight reduction in air activity owing to the weather. Enemy losses had been 16 aircraft destroyed, 3 probably destroyed and 8 damaged. Our losses had been 13 aircraft destroyed and 4 damaged.Our merchant shipping losses for the previous week amountedto 152,300 tons.In New Guinea our forces were advancing towards Kakoda.The position in the Solomon Islands was rather obscure.The War Cabinet Invited the Chiefs of Staff to ask the Joint Staff mission in Washington for fuller information about theoperations in New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, andfor an expression of their opinion as to why there were such relatively weak American forces in those areas.Our forces had advanced some 110 miles south of Tananarive.In heavy attacks at Stalingrad the Russians had lost thenorthern portion of the city, and the situation there had deteriorated since last week. But the stout defence put up by theRussians at Stalingrad had probably prevented the Germans fromattacking Leningrad, and had slowed up their advance in theCaucasus. The Germans had made no progress either towardsGrozny or in the direction of the Georgian Pass.The War Cabinet took note of these statements.Air Raids.Casualties and damage.(previous reference:W.M. Sixteen persons had been killed, 64 seriously injured and 119 slightly injured. Some industrial damage hadbeen done.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.3. First, a Royal jf reclamationwould be issued to authorise the call-up of men who read, jd theage of 18 between the 1st July and the 30th September. this could be done without legislation. Secondly, it was proposed toamend the National Service Acts so as to enable men to be registered and medically examined during their 18th year so thatthey could be called up without delay on reaching the age of 18.In discussion:, the following points were raised,: (a) In the drafting of the proposed legislation, and in announcing its introduction, care should be taken tomake it clear that men would not in fact be called upfor military service until they had reached the age of 18. (&) It had been the practice hitherto to allow young men to volunteer for the Armed Forces six months before they became liable to compulsory military service. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for India (W.P. (42) 461), enclosing the Reportof the American Technical Mission which had visited India inApril 1942 to examine the possibilities of American assistance inthe development of the industrial resources of India as a supplybase for the armed forces of the United Nations in the middle and Far East.The Secretary of State, in his Memorandum, recommended the attitude which we should take to the report at this stage. Itshould be explained that our policy had always been to give everyassistance to the expansion of India's war industry, and that anyfurther expansion would largely depend upon the help Americacould give in providing skilled supervision. There were also otherlimiting factors, e.g.y power, facilities and communications. It-should also be emphasised that care must be taken to avoid over-loading the Indian expansion programme to the prejudice of projects already in hand.Sir Ramaswami Mudalicir said that there was reason to doubt whether the American Technical Mission had taken sufficientlyinto account what had already been done to expand. India's war industry. He read an extract from a letter from the Secretaryof the Supply Department, indicating the line which theGovernment of India proposed to adopt in regard to therecommendations of this Mission. He urged that His Majesty'sGovernment should for the present leave the matter to be handled by the Government of India, and that they should not put pressureVMljhthe Government of India to take steps urged on them by theUnited- States authorities, if the Government of India thoughtthat these measures would overload the Indian expansion programme and would be detrimental to the best development ofIndia's war effort.The War Cabinet expressed general agreement with theviews set out in the Secretary of State for India'sMemorandum, and with those stated by Sir RamaswamiMudaliar. Strike in 8. The War Cabinet had under consideration the position inNorthern regard to the strike in Belfast, which was particularly affectingIreland. the Short-Harland Works.The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet a letter datedthe 16th October, which he had received from the Prime Ministerof Northern Ireland, reporting that the Northern ireland government had decided to set up a Court of Inquiry under theIndustrial Courts Act, 1919, to inquire into the causes and circumstances of the dispute.The War Cabinet were informed that this Court of Inquiryhad been set up under the chairmanship of Mr. Justice Davidson,and had started work that day.When the matter had been considered by Ministers on Friday,the 16th October, the view taken had been that it was somewhatdoubtful policy to set up a Court of Inquirj^ to enquire into thecircumstances of this unofficial strike, and that it was important that the Northern Ireland Government should adhere to the position which it was then understood they were proposing to take up,namely, that the men should return to work before the Court of inquiry was set up. Later the Northern Ireland Government hadreceded from this point of view. The reason for this had been that,on Friday, the 16th October, there had been reason to fear aconsiderable extension of the strike.Sir Frederick Leggett explained that the policy adopted inthis matter had not always been uniform, and that there wereinstances in this country in which a Court of Inquiry had beenappointed, even in unofficial strikes, before the men had returnedto work.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Great George Street, S.W. 1.October 19, 1942.
